title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Overview
Things we’ve looked at:

Things that people do: use expressions of their language to create certain (conventional) social effects.

Categorization of illocutionary effects:

performative, assertion, question, …




Things we haven’t looked at:

How they do it: locutionary act → illocutionary act (?)

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Strategy
What we need:

a (systematic, predictive, comprehensive) story about how people use expressions to perform illocutionary acts


We can work backwards.

Illocutionary act ↓

Locutionary act

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Explaining illocutionary effects
Has two parts:

the semantics of the expressions
general rules for mapping the semantics of expressions onto meanings in context

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
An extremely general rule
Grice (1975) proposes the Cooperative Principle:

“Make your conversational contribution, such as is required, at the stage at which is occurs, by the accepted purpose or direction of the talk exchange in which you are engaged.”


Basic hypotheses:

Humans are rational agents.
They are cooperative.
Meaning arises from principles of rational cooperation.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Maxims
Grice describe four maxims:

Quality
Quantity
Relation
Manner

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Quality
Part 1: only say that which you believe to be true.

Part 2: only say that which you have enough evidence for.



Who else said something like this?

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Quantity
Part 1: make your contribution as informative as necessary.

Part 2: don’t overdo it.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Manner
Four parts:

Avoid obscurity.
Avoid ambiguity.
Be brief.
Be orderly.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Questions

How should we understand the CP and the maxims?

Do they tell us how to behave?

How do they fit into Grice’s notion of meaning\(_{NN}\)?

Implicatures: just inferred, or genuinely communicated?

Variation?
